large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children through dramatic play, and introduce vocabulary (patterns, senses).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What do our eyes tell us?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that people use different languages to communicate and to express simple greetings and phrases in a language other than their own; Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts; Share background knowledge.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Use digital learning applications and programs.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children explore and talk about our five senses.
Guide children to act out which of the five senses can be used to answer the questions on the card.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we learn from using our senses?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What shapes and colors do you see?
What loud animal can you pretend to be? What sound will you make?
How can you sort those toys into different colors?
What shapes could you draw? Can you tell me a sentence about your drawing?
Build a tree with leaves rustling in the wind.
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word patterns?
Can you use things in this station to make a pattern?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder ask and answer questions and introduce vocabulary (sort, ask).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses .
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that people use different languages to communicate and to express simple greetings and phrases in a language other than their own; Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts; Share background knowledge.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of the common objects.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children classify and organize the cards into two categories: objects and living things.
Challenge children to name things around the classroom that can be classified as an object or living thing.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we learn from using our senses?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show a pattern made with circles? With squares?
Pretend you are walking up a steep set of stairs.
Can you show four patterns?
Write about your favorite cozy place. What do you do there?
Can you make a leafy path? What material will the path be made of? Can you make a sentence about your path?
Can you think of something that begins with the same letter as a letter in your name?
Can you build a pattern with blocks? How did you make your pattern?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses by Jane Brocket. Text and photographs copyright © 2014 by Jane Brocket. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Millbrook Press, a division of Lerner Publishing Group, Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Make a Connection and introduce vocabulary (sweet, sour).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Cold, Crunchy, Colorful and asking the question, What words can we use to talk about how foods taste?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that people use different languages to communicate and express simple greetings, words, and phrases in a language other than their own.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of opposites.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children make connections to the pictures in the book.
Challenge children to think of other things in the classroom that they can identify using their senses.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we learn from using our senses?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Which foods are healthy for us? Can you find pictures of healthy foods?
Can you show how you eat a sour lemon?
Can you compare the size of two fruits? Which is bigger?
Imagine a tasty dinner. Can you draw or write about your dinner?
How many senses can you name? Can you draw a picture that shows two things that we can learn from using our senses?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word sour? At the end of the word sour?
Can you build a plate with your favorite breakfast?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses by Jane Brocket. Text and photographs copyright © 2014 by Jane Brocket. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Millbrook Press, a division of Lerner Publishing Group, Inc.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas:See! Hear! Taste! Smell! and Touch!
Big Book:Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary words (taste, smell).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts See! Hear! Taste! Smell! and Touch! and Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses .
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, What can we learn from using our senses?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that people use different languages to communicate and express simple greetings, words, and phrases in a language other than their own.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of opposites.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to identify and sort things that taste good and things that taste bad.
Encourage children to talk about their favorite foods and foods they don’t like and to describe how each food tastes.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we learn from using our senses?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Look at pictures of different foods on the computer or tablet. How are they the same? Different?
Pretend to gaze up at the sky. Pretend to smell a stinky shoe.
Can you put those toys in order from heaviest to lightest?
Can you write about something you hear in the classroom?
Can you make a yummy stew?
Can you spell your name?
Can you build a very tall building? What material will it be made of?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses by Jane Brocket. Text and photographs copyright © 2014 by Jane Brocket. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Millbrook Press, a division of Lerner Publishing Group, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book:Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out scenes from Cold, Crunchy, Colorful and to introduce vocabulary words (traffic, sharp).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What kinds of sounds can we hear?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of opposites; Understand and use varied types of words.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Use increasingly complex sentence structures.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of common objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Imagine a meal with yummy foods to taste and smell. What foods would it have?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we learn from using our senses?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote your own list of favorite foods, what would you put in it?
Can you pretend to be petting a cat that is purring?
Can you find two hard materials and two soft materials?
Can you create a story about a noisy monkey?
Which materials can you use to make something rough? Smooth?
Imagine walking on the grass in your bare feet after a rainstorm. What word can you use to talk about how the grass feels?
Which materials do you use to build? What do you like about that material?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Cold, Crunchy, Colorful: Using Our Senses by Jane Brocket. Text and photographs copyright © 2014 by Jane Brocket. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Millbrook Press, a division of Lerner Publishing Group, Inc.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Able to use language for different purposes.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Typically use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Name common shapes.
Open and navigate through digital learning applications and programs.
Able to use language for different purposes.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Typically use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Able to use language for different purposes.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Typically use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Use a variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Use a variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Able to use language for different purposes.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Typically use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Use a variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Typically use sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
